SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 4 and 6  and Division 3.a (North Sea  Rockall and West of Scotland  kagerrak and Kattegat)
Description: White anglerfish (Lophius piscatorius) and black anglerfish (L. budegassa) are two closely related species. White anglerfish occur throughout the north-east Atlantic and in the Mediterranean and Black sea. They are most abundant at depths of 200- 800m but also occur in coastal waters. Black anglerfish are more restricted in their range: they do not occur as far north and are mainly found offshore between 200 and 500m depth. Juvenile white anglerfish are mainly found offshore; medium-sized fish migrate inshore and the adults move offshore again. Juvenile black anglerfish are mainly found in the western Celtic Sea and sometimes in the Bay Biscay. Anglerfish are difficult to age but they appear to be relatively fast-growing. White anglerfish grow around 15cm per year and black anglerfish around 12cm per year. Females grow larger than males and mature at larger sizes. The population structure is poorly understood but genetic diversity within the species appears to be limited. Anglerfish can migrate hundreds of kilometres and the eggs and larvae are pelagic for up to 4 months, allowing them to be dispersed over large areas. Recruitment success varies strongly between years.

SpeciesByDiv: Subareas 6-8 (Celtic Seas  English Channel  and Bay of Biscay)
Description:
Boarfish is a small, pelagic, plankton eating, shoaling species, found at depths of 0 to
600 m. The species is widely distributed from Norway to Senegal, including the
Mediterranean and oceanic island waters, but mostly south of Ireland to north Spain.
Boarfish recruit to the fishery around three to four years of age, although the
maximum age of boarfish is about 30. Spawning occurs on the Celtic Sea shelf edge
during June and July. Under optimal conditions, boarfish are capable of spawning over
an extended period of time. Maturation occurs at 3.5 years, corresponding to a total
length of approximately 10 cm. The maximum size of this species is about 18 cm.
Boarfish does not appear to be an important prey species in the Celtic Sea area.

Description: Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) are widely distributed on both sides of the north Atlantic. In the NE Atlantic they occur from Norway to the Bay of Biscay. Cod around Ireland are very fast growing and attain lengths in excess of 35cm in the first year and over 90cm as adults. Description: Blue whiting is a small, pelagic, densely-shoaling gadoid. It is widely distributed in the eastern north Atlantic from Norway to Portugal. Haddock live near the bottom on gravel, clay, or smooth, hard sand and are widespread
in the northern Atlantic. They occur mostly at bottom depths between 10 and 200m.
Haddock are moderately large gadoids with a diet consisting largely of benthic molluscs,
crustaceans, worms and small fish. Small haddock are important prey for saithe and large
cod.
The waters around Ireland provide important spawning and nursery areas for haddock.
Irish waters are at the southerly end of the distribution of haddock, allowing them to
grow fast and mature early. They reach a length of around 27cm after two years of
growth and most haddock are mature at age two. However, haddock are a coldadapted
species and warm winters have been linked to poor recruitment success.
All haddock stocks occasionally produce extremely large numbers of recruits, which can increase the stock size
dramatically.

Description:
Black sole (also called Dover sole) are flat fish which lie buried on sandy or muddy
seabed. They feed primarily at night on small crustaceans, worms and bivalve molluscs.
In common with many flatfish, sole are fast growing as juveniles, slowing down as they
mature. Females grow larger than the males. They can reach lengths of up to 70cm or
weights of up to 3kg. Sole are quite solitary marine and estuarine fish, and the local
environment may contribute to variable growth rates.
Females reach maturity by ca. 6yrs and an average mature female can produce in the
region of 150,000 - 200,000 eggs a year. They spawn in spring and early summer and
become mature at 3-6 years when they are around 25-30cm long. Juveniles are
found in the first 2-3 years in coastal nurseries before they move in to deeper waters.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.b and 7.c (West of Ireland)
Description:
Black sole (also called Dover sole) are flat fish which lie buried on sandy or muddy
seabed. They feed primarily at night on small crustaceans, worms and bivalve molluscs.
In common with many flatfish, sole are fast growing as juveniles, slowing down as they
mature. Females grow larger than the males. They can reach lengths of up to 70cm or
weights of up to 3kg. Sole are quite solitary marine and estuarine fish, and the local
environment may contribute to variable growth rates.
Females reach maturity by ca. 6yrs and an average mature female can produce in the
region of 150,000 - 200,000 eggs a year. They spawn in spring and early summer and
become mature at 3-6 years when they are around 25-30cm long. Juveniles are
found in the first 2-3 years in coastal nurseries before they move in to deeper waters.

SpeciesByDiv: Divisions 7.b-c (West of Ireland)
Description: Plaice (Pleuronectes platessa) are found throughout the Atlantic coast of Europe and in the western Mediterranean. They are usually found in waters less than 100m depth. Older fish are found in deeper water. Plaice are most commonly found on sandy, muddy or gravel bottom. Small fish are found in intertidal areas and there is evidence to suggest homing behaviour. The Irish Sea is an important spawning ground for plaice. Spawning occurs off the bottom from February to April in the Irish Sea and is dependent on water temperature. Males reach maturity between 2 and 6 years, and females between 3 and 7 years, with age at maturity again being dependent on water temperature. Young plaice feed on small worms and shrimp. As they grow their diet becomes more varied and they eat small crustaceans, crabs, mussels, scallops and shrimp.

Description:
Saithe is a large Gadoid, reaching maximum size of 130cm. It is a cold-water species distributed throughout the
northern Atlantic. Saithe live in shoals and occur close to the bottom, in midwater and even near the surface.

Description:
European sea bass is a marine member of the Order Perciformes and can be found distributed around the coasts of all countries in the north-west Atlantic region. It is a slow going species, attaining sexual maturation between 4 to 7 years of age and can live to over 25 years. Juvenile sea bass are commonly found in inshore nurseries such as estuaries where the then begin to form shoals as adolescents (3-4 years of age). Adult sea bass typically spend warmer periods feeding in shallow inshore waters, migrating to offshore spawning grounds in late autumn. 
Sea bass are opportunistic feeders eating a wide variety of benthic invertebrates and both demersal and pelagic prey also.
Tagging experiments have found sea bass to show high fidelity when in inshore waters but also capable of making considerable migrations offshore.
TAC2018: Since 1990, there has been a ban on commercial fishing of sea bass by Irish vessels. As a result, reported landings from Irish waters are relatively low. Recreational catches of sea bass are also strictly controlled with a bag limit of one fish per angler per day with a minimum size limit of 42cm.

Description:
Albacore is a medium sized, pelagic, fish-eating, found offshore, surface and mid waters between 14 o and 21o
Celsius. It is found from the Azores and Canaries north to Ireland, and westwards to the central USA. Separate
stocks occur in the south Atlantic and the Mediterranean. It is fast growing and recruits to the fishery by age 1,
with maximum age of 15 years. Maturation occurs at 5 years, corresponding to fork length of approximately
90 cm, and maximum size is 128 cm. Juveniles migrate north to SW Ireland in summer, to feed in surface waters.
Adults migrate, at depths from 50-150 m, to spawn off Venezuela, in the Gulf of Mexico and Sargasso Sea.
Spawning ensues from April to September.
TAC2018: r the last three years, 2,400 to 2,500 t of albacore were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic pair-trawls. This roughly equals the Irish quota with 2017 having the highest catch. In 2015 and 2016 most landings were from the south-west of Ireland in 7.j,k,. France is the other dominant country fishing in this area. While limited landings from the Bay of Biscay are usual at the start of the season, this is where the bulk of the landings was coming from in 2017. In 2017, the price per kilogramme paid to Irish fishermen was about &#8364 2.60 and landings were worth approximately &#8364 6,469,000.
TAC2017: For the last three years, about 2400 tonnes of albacore were caught and landed annually by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic pair-trawls. This roughly equals the Irish quota although a slight decrease occurred during this period. Most landings were from the south-west of Ireland in 7.j,k, with occasional landings further to the south, usually at the start of the season. France is the other dominant country fishing in this area. In 2016, the price per kilogramme paid to Irish fishermen almost doubled to about &#8364 4 and landings were worth approximately &#8364 9,369,781 for Irish vessels
TAC2016: On average approximately 2,400 tonnes of albacore annually were caught and landed by Irish vessels using mainly pelagic pair-trawls between 2013 and 2015. This equals the annual quota. Most landings are from the south-west of Ireland in 7j,k, with occasional landings further to the south, usually at the start of the season. France is the other dominant country fishing in this area. In 2015 landings were worth approximately &#8364 5,163,928 for Irish vessels.

The SCRS advice states catches in 2018 should not exceed 33,600 t if a harvest control rule is adopted, otherwise they should not exceed 28,000 t.

ICESAdvice2015:

Description:
Bluefin tuna is the largest tuna, and one of the largest fish of all. It is a pelagic, fish-eating species, found from the
surface to depths of up to 1,000 m, and in temperatures from 3o and 30o Celsius. It is found throughout the
north Atlantic including very cold waters extending into the Mediterranean. A separate stock occurs in the west
Atlantic. It is fast growing and recruits to the fishery by age 1, with maximum age of at least 20 years. Maturation
occurs at 4 years, corresponding to fork length of approximately 115 cm, and maximum size is 400 cm. Juveniles
migrate north to SW Ireland in summer, to feed in surface waters. Adults migrate, at depths from 50-150 m, to
spawn off Venezuela, in the Gulf of Mexico and Sargasso Sea, and in the Mediterranean Sea. Spawning ensues
from May to June, but probably only occurs every 2-3 years.

Description: Sprat (Sprattus sprattus) are a short lived, fast growing species. Their size range on the Irish Groundfish surveys is between 3 to 17cm with a mean size of 9cm. Sprat are not aged at the groundfish survey, but in general they reach maturity in their first to second year and rarely live longer than four years. Sprat feed on plankton and are an important prey fish with several fish species as well as sea birds and marine mammals feeding on this species.

Value followed the same trend as catch decreasing from &#8364 2,097,000 to &#8364 881,000 over the years 2015-2017. Sprat appears to be a secondary target species for the Irish fleet, i.e. vessels target it when their primary target is not accessible.
